files.name: /etc/inap/miro/inap-miro-route-optimizer-simulation/latency-buckets.properties
contents: # dynamic_bucket_size should be true to enable. Otherwise W generator will use fixed bucket sizes
# size_of_bucket is the default value for fixed bucket sizes or if the value cant be calculated for dynamic buckets
# number_of_buckets is the maximum number of buckets that the system should use for calculating W values
# outlier_stdev_multiplier is the standard deviation multiplier to identify outliers when calculating W values
# the way the system calculates outliers is for all NSP latency measures (for each prefix) calculate standard
# deviation and if the difference between the lowest latency and the second lowest latency is more that
# the stdev * the stdev_multiplier, the lowest latency is mark as an outlier.
# latency_divisor is used to calculate the bucket size for dynamic buckest: bucket_size = best_latency / latency_divisor
# if latency_divisor is 10, then the bucket size is 10 percent of the best latency. For example 5ms buckets if the
# truncate_w_values will truncate W values to 2 decimal points to add priority based on previous solution, manual bump,
# and raw latency. The W value would be w.wwxyzz where x is previous sol bump, y is manual, and zz is bump based on raw latency
# add_raw_latency_bump adds a little bump 0.0000zz to the W value based on latency ranking

files.name: /etc/inap/miro/inap-miro-bgp-service/do-not-route.properties
contents: # This optional file  should contain PREFIX, PEER_ADDRESS pairs that should never be routed.
# These prefixes will be added to a do-not-route list in the bgp_master and disable the ability
# for these listed prefixes to be stored in the bgp_master's prefix lookup table for the given
# peer(s), therefore disabling the ability for the prefix to be announced or withdrawn automatically
# by the bgp_master (any prefix can still be manually routed by 'command' for a configured peer).
# Use the word 'all' in place of the required PEER_ADDRESS to indicate that a do-not-route prefix
# should be applied for all configured peers. One PREFIX, PEER_ADDRESS pair per line.

files.name: /etc/inap/miro/inap-miro-route-optimizer-service/optimizer-knobs.properties
contents: # All percentage values should be between 0 and 100
# percentage_relax is the relaxation percentage based on the total amount of traffic
# for instance, for 10G of traffic if and 10% we will relax to 11G
# percentage_latency is the weight for the latency when calculating W
# percentage_loss is the weight for loss when calculating W
# if the viable bandwidth per NSP is less than the percentage_viable_minimum percent of the total traffic
# we should adjust the BWMax for the NSP. This basically means that an NSP can't handle much traffic (e.g. peering
# networks like Voxel), and we should tell optimizer not to waste time trying to put more traffic on those networks
# percentage_viable_reduction is the percentage we want to reduce the maximum bandwidth for an NSP that can't handle

files.name: /etc/inap/miro/inap-miro-route-optimizer-service/optimizer-timers.properties
contents: #maximum-iteration-time defines the maximum time we can wait for a solution
#from the linear programming solver (0 for infinite - not recommended)
#minimum-running-interval defines how fast the optimizer can generate new solutions
#that's in case the optimizer solves the problem too fast
#inactive-timeout is a timer to generate warnings if the optimizer is inactive
#when the optimizer does not receive W values for w-timeout seconds,
#it times out and requests new W values to the W generator.
#the data-ttl defines a timer to age out table entries
#notification-timeout how often should it send overcommits notification messages over rabbit

files.name: /etc/inap/miro/inap-miro-common/bgp-sessions-primary.properties
contents: # (one line per session; a leading '#' generalComments out a line)
# (a blank line signifies the end of the active session configurations)
# (one 'recv' session per router (sessions that collect routes from routers))
# (one 'send' session per nsp uplink (sessions that send optimized routes to routers))
# (replace examples in CAPS with NSP AS numbers or appropriate IP addresses)
# ROUTERNAME, recv, ipv6, ROUTER_IPV6, MIRO_IPV6, MIRO_IPV4
# ROUTERNAME, send, ipv4, NSP_ASN, NSP_NEXTHOP_IPV4, FAKE_NEXTHOP_IPV4, ROUTER_IPV4, MIRO_IPV4
# ROUTERNAME, send, ipv6, NSP_ASN, NSP_NEXTHOP_IPV6, FAKE_NEXTHOP_IPV6, ROUTER_IPV6, MIRO_IPV6, MIRO_IPV4
